title: Aaron Bates
text:
Aaron Bates (born March 10, 1984) is an American retired professional <a href="baseball">baseball</a> <a href="first%20baseman">first baseman</a>. He played in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> for the <a href="Boston%20Red%20Sox">Boston Red Sox</a> in 2009. He is currently the assistant hitting coach for the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Dodgers">Los Angeles Dodgers</a>.
College.
NCAA.
Bates played <a href="college%20baseball">college baseball</a> for both the <a href="NC%20State%20Wolfpack%20baseball">NC State Wolfpack</a> and the <a href="San%20Jose%20State%20Spartans%20baseball">San Jose State Spartans</a>. He was a freshman <a href="All-America">All American</a> for the <a href="San%20Jose%20State%20Spartans%20baseball">San Jose State Spartans</a> and twice named <a href="All-America">All American</a> for the <a href="NC%20State%20Wolfpack%20baseball">NC State Wolfpack</a>. His best year coming in 2005, when he had arguably the greatest offensive season in wolfpack history hitting .425-12-64 and was drafted in the 8th round by the <a href="Florida%20Marlins">Florida Marlins</a>. However, he returned to school for his junior season and hit .356-10-56 and was then selected by the <a href="Boston%20Red%20Sox">Boston Red Sox</a> in 2006.
Collegiate summer.
He played in the <a href="Cape%20Cod%20Baseball%20League">Cape Cod Baseball League</a> for the <a href="Brewster%20Whitecaps">Brewster Whitecaps</a> in the summer of 2005. He was named a Cape Cod League All Star alongside future <a href="MLB">MLB</a> stars <a href="Evan%20Longoria">Evan Longoria</a>, <a href="Justin%20Masterson">Justin Masterson</a>, <a href="Daniel%20Bard">Daniel Bard</a> and <a href="Chris%20Coghlan">Chris Coghlan</a>. Bates also won the 2005 All Star game Home Run Derby.
Professional.
Boston Red Sox.
He was drafted in <a href="2006%20MLB%20Draft">2006</a> in the 3rd round by the <a href="Boston%20Red%20Sox">Boston Red Sox</a>. His first professional season was split between the <a href="Lowell%20Spinners">Lowell Spinners</a> and <a href="Greenville%20Drive">Greenville Drive</a>. In 2007, Bates began the year with the <a href="Lancaster%20JetHawks">Lancaster JetHawks</a> before being promoted to the AA <a href="Portland%20Sea%20Dogs">Portland Sea Dogs</a>. He played with Sea Dogs until June 2009, when he was promoted to AAA <a href="Pawtucket%20Red%20Sox">Pawtucket Red Sox</a>.
In May 2009, he was the <a href="Eastern%20League%20%281938%E2%80%932020%29">Eastern League</a> Player of the Month while playing with the Sea Dogs.
On July 6, 2009, Bates was called up to the Red Sox to play at first base after <a href="Jeff%20Bailey">Jeff Bailey</a> injured his ankle in a game two days before. He had four hits in 11 at-bats with the Red Sox, with his first hit being an RBI single to center field off <a href="Rom%C3%A1n%20Col%C3%B3n">Román Colón</a> of the <a href="Kansas%20City%20Royals">Kansas City Royals</a>.
On July 26, 2010, the Red Sox outrighted Bates to Pawtucket, thus removing him from the 40-man roster.
In March 2011 he was released by the Red Sox.
Minnesota Twins.
On May 8, 2011 he was signed by the <a href="Minnesota%20Twins">Minnesota Twins</a> to a minor league contract and sent to Rochester of the <a href="International%20League">International League</a>. He went on to finish 3rd in <a href="International%20League">International League</a> in <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batting average</a>, .316 and lead the league in <a href="on-base%20percentage">on-base percentage</a> at .408. Bates then re-signed with the <a href="Minnesota%20Twins">Minnesota Twins</a> for the 2012 season, before declaring free agency. In Spring Training 2012, he hit .400 (8-20) with the Major League Team, but was sent to the AAA <a href="Rochester%20Red%20Wings">Rochester Red Wings</a> of the <a href="International%20League">International League</a> to start the season.
Bates was then released by the Twins on May 15, 2012 due to the subsequent demotions of then Twins 3rd baseman <a href="Danny%20Valencia">Danny Valencia</a>, <a href="MLB">MLB</a> veteran <a href="Sean%20Burroughs">Sean Burroughs</a> and rising star <a href="Chris%20Parmelee">Chris Parmelee</a>.
St. Louis Cardinals.
On May 22, 2012, Bates signed a minor league deal with the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Cardinals">St. Louis Cardinals</a>. He was subsequently released by the Cardinals at the end of July 2012 and signed with the <a href="Sugar%20Land%20Skeeters">Sugar Land Skeeters</a> of the <a href="Atlantic%20League%20of%20Professional%20Baseball">Atlantic League of Professional Baseball</a>.
Los Angeles Dodgers.
On January 29, 2014, he signed a minor league contract with the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Dodgers">Los Angeles Dodgers</a> and was assigned to the AA <a href="Chattanooga%20Lookouts">Chattanooga Lookouts</a>. He spent most of the season on the disabled list and only played in 11 games, hitting .176.
Winter Leagues.
Bates played in the <a href="Liga%20de%20B%C3%A9isbol%20Profesional%20Roberto%20Clemente">Liga de Béisbol Profesional Roberto Clemente</a> from 2008 to 2013. Playing for the <a href="Leones%20de%20Ponce%20%28baseball%29">Leones de Ponce</a> in the winter of 2008, before being traded to the <a href="Criollos%20de%20Caguas%20%28baseball%29">Criollos de Caguas</a>. The Criollos played in the <a href="Puerto%20Rican%20Professional%20Baseball%20League">LBPRC</a> championship series all four years he played with them. Winning championships in 2011 and 2013. In 2011, Bates played with Criollos in the <a href="2011%20Caribbean%20Series">2011 Caribbean Series</a> hitting .333 over the course of 6 games. It was held in <a href="Mayag%C3%BCez%2C%20Puerto%20Rico">Mayagüez, Puerto Rico</a> and they finished tied for 2nd with the <a href="Dominican%20Republic">Dominican Republic</a>. He most recently played in the <a href="2013%20Caribbean%20Series">2013 Caribbean Series</a> hitting .333 (2-6) which took place in <a href="Hermosillo%2C%20Mexico">Hermosillo, Mexico</a>
Bates' grandparents are from <a href="Ponce%2C%20Puerto%20Rico">Ponce, Puerto Rico</a>, thus allowing him to play as domestic in the Liga de Béisbol Profesional Roberto Clemente.
Coaching.
He retired from playing to become an assistant coach for the Dodgers rookie class <a href="Arizona%20League%20Dodgers">Arizona League Dodgers</a> team in 2015. In 2017, he was named hitting coach of the single-A <a href="Great%20Lakes%20Loons">Great Lakes Loons</a>. He spent 2018 as a minor league coordinator before being named as the Dodgers Major League assistant hitting coach for the 2019 season.
Personal.
Bates grew up in the small coastal town of <a href="Santa%20Cruz%2C%20California">Santa Cruz</a>, <a href="California">California</a>. He attended <a href="Soquel%20High%20School">Soquel High School</a> for his freshmen year, before transferring to <a href="Archbishop%20Mitty%20High%20School">Archbishop Mitty High School</a> in <a href="San%20Jose%2C%20California">San Jose, California</a> where he played both <a href="American%20football">football</a> and <a href="baseball">baseball</a>. His senior season he was the <a href="Quarterback">Quarterback</a> on the football team which went 12-1 and captured its first <a href="West%20Catholic%20Athletic%20League">West Catholic Athletic League</a> title in 25 years.
He was inducted into the <a href="Archbishop%20Mitty%20High%20School">Archbishop Mitty High School</a> Hall of Fame in January 2013 with General Manager and Vice President <a href="Doug%20Wilson%20%28ice%20hockey%29">Doug Wilson</a> of the <a href="San%20Jose%20Sharks">San Jose Sharks</a> giving his acceptance speech.<a href="http%3A//www.Mitty.com/athletics">Archbishop Mitty High School | Athletics</a>
Bates is married to Lacey Wilson Bates, Miss Massachusetts USA 2010.
